Don't miss out
Subscribe to STAT+ today, for the best life sciences journalism in the industry
Walmart offers way to turn leftover opioids into useless gel
============================================================
_By_ Associated PressJan. 17, 2018
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
   !
Walmart is helping customers get rid of leftover opioids by giving them packets that turn the painkillers into a useless gel. Patrick Sison/AP
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
Walmart is helping customers get rid of leftover opioids by giving them packets that turn the addictive painkillers into a useless gel.
The retail giant announced Wednesday that it will provide the packets free with opioid prescriptions filled at its 4,700 U.S. pharmacies.
advertisement
The small packets, made by DisposeRX, contain a powder that is poured into prescription bottles. When mixed with warm water, the powder turns the pills into a biodegradable gel that can be thrown in the trash.
It works on other prescription drugs and for pills, tablets, capsules, liquids or patches, according to DisposeRx.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Around 4 million Americans are addicted to prescription painkillers, according to the Drug Enforcement Administration. The agency says these drugs are often obtained from friends and family who leave them in home medicine cabinets.
advertisement
Research has shown that surgery patients often end up with  and store them improperly at home. Authorities say opioid painkillers should be kept in their original packaging and locked inside a cabinet out of the reach of children.
Walmart says its pharmacy customers can request a free packet at any time. The company also will offer patients with a chronic opioid prescription a packet every six months.
Painkiller maker Mallinckrodt PLC has a similar program. It said last fall that it has donated about 1.5 million drug disposal pouches across the country and will increase that total to 2 million early this year.
Sign up for Morning Rounds
--------------------------
Your daily dose of news in health and medicine.
Please enter a valid email address.
Some drugstore chains like CVS and Walgreens also collect unused medications at many of their stores. People can also take leftovers to hospital pharmacies or police stations.
Unused prescriptions also can...[Content truncated]

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses Walmart providing kits to turn leftover opioids into a gel. While it mentions 'gel,' it is related to drug disposal and has no relevance to water turning into a gelatinous substance.

Breaking News
Walmart offers way to turn leftover opioids into useless gel
============================================================
The retail giant announced Wednesday that it will provide the packets free with opioid prescriptions filled at its 4,700 U.S. pharmacies.
! !
Credit: smartstock / Thinkstock
A bottle with a hydrocodone (the generic name for drug sold under other names by various pharmaceutical companies) label and hydrocodone tablets.
Author: Associated Press
Published: 9:07 AM EST January 17, 2018
Updated: 9:09 AM EST January 17, 2018
]
Walmart is helping customers get rid of leftover opioids by giving them packets that turn the addictive painkillers into a useless gel.
The retail giant announced Wednesday that it will provide the packets free with opioid prescriptions filled at its 4,700 U.S. pharmacies.
The small packets, made by DisposeRX, contain a powder that is poured into prescription bottles. When mixed with warm water, the powder turns the pills into a biodegradable gel that can be thrown in the trash.
Research has shown that surgery patients often end up with leftover opioid painkillers and store the drugs improperly at home
Walmart says the powder also works with other prescription drugs. The company says its pharmacy customers can request a free packet at any time.

The retailers, along with Michaels and others, acted after pressure from regulators, lawmakers, and parent advocates
Amid mounting pressure, Amazon, Walmart, and Target tell Consumer Reports that they have changed their policies on water beads: The companies will no longer allow the products to be sold if they are being marketed for children. 
“In the interest of safety, Amazon will no longer allow the sale of water beads that are marketed to children, including as toys, art supplies, or for sensory play,” an Amazon spokesperson told CR. “We work hard to ensure the products offered in our store are safe, and we have teams dedicated to developing and updating our policies, evaluating listings, and continuously monitoring our store to prevent unsafe and noncompliant products from being listed.”
Amazon’s sellers will have to comply with the new policy by Dec. 22. The company says that the popular water bead brand Orbeez will now be prohibited and that water beads sold as ammunition for “gel blaster” guns will not be allowed if they are marketed for children.
Walmart tells CR it will prohibit the sale of all water bead toys and craft supplies that are marketed for children under age 9, both in stores and online.
Target initially declined to comment, but after the publication of this story, the company told CR that it has also decided to change its policy regarding water beads.
“At Target, our top priority is the safety of our guests,” said Emily Bisek, a Target spokesperson. “Given growing safety...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Consumer Reports is highly credible, known for its rigorous testing and research in various consumer products. It has a strong reputation for truthfulness and accuracy. As a resource focused on consumer protection, it can provide insights into product safety, such as the claim regarding Walmart-brand water.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the banning of water bead toys marketed towards children due to safety concerns, but it does not relate to Walmart-brand water turning into a dangerous gelatin substance. The connection to the claim is tenuous at best.

FILE - In an Aug. 26, 2016, file photo, people walk in and out of a Walmart store, in Dallas. Walmart announced new moves Monday, Oct. 9, 2017, to speed up the return process for online purchases, including letting some shoppers keep the stuff they don‚Äôt want and still get a refund. (AP Photo/Tony Gutierrez, File) _Tony Gutierrez / AP, File_
By The Associated Press, Associated Press
January 17, 2018
*   
*

Walmart is helping customers get rid of leftover opioids by giving them packets that turn the addictive painkillers into a useless gel.
The retail giant announced Wednesday that it will provide the packets free with opioid prescriptions filled at its 4,700 U.S. pharmacies.
The small packets, made by DisposeRX, contain a powder that is poured into prescription bottles. When mixed with warm water, the powder turns the pills into a biodegradable gel that can be thrown in the trash.
It works on other prescription drugs and for pills, tablets, capsules, liquids or patches, according to DisposeRx.
Around 4 million Americans are addicted to prescription painkillers, according to the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. The agency says these drugs are often obtained from friends and family who leave them in home medicine cabinets.
Advertisement:
Research has shown that surgery patients often end up with leftover opioid painkillers and store them improperly at home. Authorities say opioid painkillers should be kept in their original packaging and locked inside a cabinet out of the reach of children.
Walmart says its pharmacy customers can request a free packet at any time. The company also will offer patients with a chronic opioid prescription a packet every six months.

Walmart Offers Way To Turn Leftover Opioids Into Useless Gel
============================================================
] January 17, 2018 / 5:27 AM CST / CBS Texas
*   
*   
*   
Walmart is helping customers get rid of leftover opioids by giving them packets that turn the addictive painkillers into a useless gel.
The retail giant announced Wednesday that it will provide the packets free with opioid prescriptions filled at its 4,700 U.S. pharmacies.
The small packets, made by DisposeRX, contain a powder that is poured into prescription bottles. When mixed with warm water, the powder turns the pills into a biodegradable gel that can be thrown in the trash.
Research has shown that surgery patients often end up with leftover opioid painkillers and store the drugs improperly at home  
Walmart says the powder also works with other prescription drugs.
The company says its pharmacy customers can request a free packet at any time.

article.articlebody: Press Center View Press Center En español » BENTONVILLE, Ark. – January 17, 2018 – In an effort to help curb abuse and misuse, Walmart is launching a first-of-its kind opioid disposal...

website_content.content:
Jan. 17, 2018
En español »
BENTONVILLE, Ark. – January 17, 2018 – In an effort to help curb abuse and misuse, Walmart is launching a first-of-its kind opioid disposal solution – available at no cost – in all company pharmacies.* Known as DisposeRx, the small packet contains ingredients that, according to the manufacturer, when emptied into a pill bottle with warm water, ultimately enable patients to responsibly dispose of leftover medications in their trash. 
According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration and the National Institute of Drug Abuse, more than 65 percent of people misusing prescription opioids are getting them from family and friends, and personal prescriptions are one of the main sources of nonmedical opioid abuse. DisposeRx provides a virtually effortless way for patients to destroy leftover opioids and a way to do so without ever leaving home. 
The innovative disposal solution will now be provided in addition to ongoing counseling available to Walmart patients on proper opioid use when filling an opioid prescription at any one of its 4,700 pharmacies nationwide. Now, pharmacists can also counsel patients on how to use DisposeRx and distribute an opioid awareness brochure outlining risks and helpful resources. 
“The health and safety of our patients is a critical priority; that’s why we’re taking an active role in fighting our nation’s opioid issue – an issue that has affected so many families and communities across America,” said Marybeth Hays, executive vice president of Consumables and Health and Wellness at Walmart U.S. “While this issue requires many resources to solve, we are confident this unique, easy-to-use disposal solution, DisposeRx, will make a meaningful impact on the lives of many...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Similar to www.walmart.com, this is Walmart's corporate website, which contains company press releases and information. It provides corporate insight but often lacks independent verification and can reflect the company's interests, leading to a possible bias.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence is again focused on opioid disposal, reinforcing the information in previous evidences about turning solids into gel for safe disposal, but it holds no relevance to the claim concerning water.

metatags.og:title: Help - Odd chicken texture
metatags.og:description: I have been having an issue on and off with the texture of my chicken.  The chicken is fully cooked through (I can tell based on internal...
metatags.sailthru.author: JessicaHansen

website_content.content:
I have been having an issue on and off with the texture of my chicken.  The chicken is fully cooked through (I can tell based on internal temp, time in the oven, color of the chicken and juices), but the texture of the chicken is funny, almost like it hasn't been thoroughly cooked.  When I cut into the chicken I feel resistance (like you would when butchering raw chicken rather than cutting/carving cooked chicken) and there is a strange almost squeaky mouth feel.  This has happened to me  with bone in, skin on chicken breasts and also skinless boneless breasts.  Usually when this happens to me, there are some pieces of chicken that are fine, but others that are decidedly not.  At first, I thought it was a result of cooking frozen chicken that hadn't fully thawed.  But last night, this happened when I roasted some never frozen bone in breasts from the fridge.  Could this have something to do with how I'm cooking the meat?  Or is it a sad byproduct of factory farmed chicken breasts?  Has anyone else had this problem?
Our best tips for eating thoughtfully and living joyfully, right in your inbox.

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Food52 is a reputable site dedicated to food-related content, including recipes and kitchen tips. While not a news website, it emphasizes accuracy in cooking and food safety, potentially providing a useful secondary perspective on culinary products like water.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence is completely unrelated to the claim about Walmart water and discusses an unrelated kitchen issue regarding chicken texture.

Shooting of teen in Goddard Walmart parking lot spotlights concerns with ‘Orbeez Challenge’
===========================================================================================
By  and 
Published: Jun. 5, 2024 at 10:33 PM CDT
WICHITA, Kan. (KWCH) - New information released Wednesday provides information into what police said led up to . A document that 12 News obtained details circumstances surrounding the shooting of an 18-year-old and the arrest of 47-year-old Ruben Contreras.
Contreras is charged with attempted first-degree murder in connection with the May 11 shooting of the teen.
Court documents say the teen and two of his friends were driving around the Walmart parking, allegedly shooting a gel blaster at people. Contreras’ daughter was one of the people the teens allegedly shot at. She called her father.
Detectives said Contreras arrived in the parking lot and attempted to confront the teens as they were in a car backing out of a parking space. That’s when Contreras ran to the driver’s side and appeared to pull out a gun, firing one round into the vehicle, and striking the driver. The car continued forward and crashed.
The driver remained in the car while his friends ran away, police said. Contreras remained at the scene and was taken into custody.
The shooting highlights a social media game called the “Orbeez Challenge.” in which teens use a gel blaster that shoots water-based gel beads. Across the U.S., police report seeing cases where kids take the challenge too far, even freezing the beads. The action leads to criminal charges.
This week, 12 News is taking a closer look into the issues surrounding the “Orbeez Challenge.” We spoke with a teen named Tomas...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: KWCH is a local news outlet based in Kansas. While it provides local news and coverage, the credibility can vary based on resources and scrutiny applied. It may report on consumer news but might not have the depth for factual verification compared to larger networks.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence alludes to a social media trend involving gel blasters but does not provide any direct connection to water or Walmart's water transforming into a gel.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... parking lot erupted into real gunfire
====================================================================================================================
By 
Published: 16:39 EDT, 6 June 2024 | Updated: 16:42 EDT, 6 June 2024
*   
*   
*   
*   
**34** shares
A high school senior has been left paralyzed from waist down after a water pistol fight escalated into a real shooting in a  parking.
Anakin Zehring and his friends were shooting a toy water gel blaster at two other teens on May 11 at the Walmart Supercenter in Goddard,  when things took a turn for the worse.
One of the teens that Anakin and his friends got with the water gun reportedly ended up calling a relative who allegedly shot the 18-year-old with a real gun while he was sitting in the driver’s seat of a blue car.
The Sedgwick County Sheriff's Office has since arrested Ruben Contreras, 47, in connection to the shooting and charged him with attempted first-degree murder.
!
Anakin Zehring and his friends were shooting a toy water gel blaster at two other teens when he was shot in the spine by one of the teens' relatives
!
The Sedgwick County Sheriff's Office has since arrested Ruben Contreras, 47, (pictured) in connection to the shooting and charged him with attempted first-degree murder
Anakin's father Jeremy Zehring explained what happened at the scene: 'I pulled up his locator on his car, and I noticed it was at the Goddard Walmart.
'So I started calling him and calling him. It kept going to voicemail.'
After hearing police reports that a shooting occurred in the same parking lot, the distressed father frantically reached the area.
'I tried to rush to the car, but they stopped me, they said it was an investigation. I was like, well, where's my son? And they're like Anakin. I said Yes. Where's my son? And they're like, well, he's been transported to the hospital,' he told .
The teen's mother, Kenly has since revealed that the bullet caused significant damage to Anakin's body.
His duodenum (upper part of the small intestine) was left punctured and spinal cord damaged which caused loss of sensation from the waist down.
!
The teen was a senior at Campus High School and planned to become an engineer after graduating
!
